description: Medium - Land Reform and Structural Problems

questions.question: Why did the Senate strongly oppose Tiberius Gracchus's land redistribution proposal?
options: They believed the proposal violated sacred religious laws governing agricultural land
They were concerned it would cause inflation in Rome's economy
They worried it would provoke a rebellion among enslaved agricultural workers
They feared it would reduce their own wealth and power by limiting their control of public land
They believed farmland should be left wild to preserve its natural state
questions.text_reference: Section 8 - The Senate's Response: Obstruction and Crisis

questions.question: What interconnected problems did Rome face by the early 2nd century BCE?
options: Military weakness and inability to defend Mediterranean territories from rivals
Excessive grain production and falling agricultural prices destroying farmers' livelihoods
Dependence on mercenary soldiers and loss of traditional military structures
Isolation from Mediterranean trade and declining commerce
The land problem, food supply problem, wealth inequality, military recruitment issues, and Senate dominance
questions.text_reference: Section 7 - The Structural Problems Rome Couldn't Solve

questions.question: How did the explosion of slavery after the Punic Wars transform Roman agriculture?
options: Enslaved workers replaced free laborers and eliminated wage costs for large estate owners
Small farmers purchased enslaved workers to increase their productivity and profits
The government forced all agricultural land to be worked exclusively by enslaved people
Enslaved workers staged massive revolts that destroyed agricultural production entirely
Trade restrictions prevented enslaved workers from being used in agriculture
questions.text_reference: Section 3 - The Growth of Slavery and the Collapse of Small Farming

questions.question: Why Rome's founding mythology was incompatible with its 2nd century BCE reality? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Rome was founded on the ideal of the independent farmer-citizen defending his property and the Republic
Rome had actually been founded as an urban city-state dependent on merchant commerce
By the 2nd century, Rome was becoming dependent on urban populations and patron support like Athens
Rome's traditional virtue of virtus was embodied in the farmer-soldier figure that was disappearing
Rome had always been a mercenary-based military power with no tradition of citizen-soldiers
questions.text_reference: Section 5 - Comparison to Greece: Why Rome's Crisis Was Different

questions.question: What was the primary objective of Tiberius Gracchus's land reform?
options: Establish large imperial estates controlled directly by the government
Redistribute ager publicus (public land) to create a class of independent farmer-citizens
Eliminate latifundia entirely and prohibit any large landholdings
Convert all agricultural land to communal ownership with no private property rights
Provide enslaved workers with small plots of land and their freedom

questions.question: What powers did Tiberius hold as tribune that allowed him to challenge Senate obstruction?
options: He could arrest senators and put them on trial without Senate approval
He had command of military forces loyal to him personally
He could execute laws directly without requiring Senate or popular approval
He could redistribute public funds without accounting to the government
He could propose legislation and veto Senate decisions he believed harmed the people

questions.question: Why was the murder of Tiberius Gracchus shocking to Roman society beyond the violence itself?
options: It was the first time any politician had been killed in Roman history
Tribunes were considered inviolable and sacred by law, and the Senate murdered one with impunity
It violated religious laws regarding violence during voting assemblies
It demonstrated that Rome's military forces were too weak to maintain order
It proved that the plebs were no longer loyal to the Republic
questions.text_reference: Section 8 - The Violation of Sacred Law

questions.question: What did Gaius Gracchus's grain law (lex frumentaria) accomplish?
options: Prohibited the export of grain from Italy to ensure local food security
Eliminated grain trade with foreign powers and made Rome self-sufficient in agriculture
Gave priority access to grain supplies for military personnel and their families
Provided subsidized grain at fixed, affordable prices for Rome's urban population
Transferred control of grain production from wealthy owners to the government
questions.text_reference: Section 8 - Gaius Gracchus: The Continuation of Reform

questions.question: What made Gaius's proposal to expand citizenship to Italian allies revolutionary? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Shifting political power away from Rome itself toward Italy as a whole
Threatening the Senate's ability to maintain Rome's exclusive control over its allies
Granting Italian allies the same legal protections as Roman citizens
Fundamentally challenging Rome's imperial hierarchy that kept allies subordinate to Rome
Creating a unified political community across Rome and Italy with equal voting rights
questions.text_reference: Section 8 - Gaius Gracchus: The Continuation of Reform

questions.question: What was the long-term impact of the Gracchi reforms despite their violent suppression?
options: Rome immediately collapsed into civil war and ceased to function as a state
Some reforms persisted (grain law, land redistribution, citizenship grants) and demonstrated the system's fragility
The Senate consolidated power completely and prevented any further reform for centuries
Rome returned to the exact conditions that existed before the Gracchi challenged the system
The Republic achieved complete social equality and eliminated all class distinctions
questions.text_reference: Section 8 - The Aftermath: The System Breaks, But Survives for Now
